Given any random year of civilian rule, chance of a coup would have to be about 10%. This is especially true when the Army has been out of power for an extended period, at least in a de jure sense even if it is not true on de facto grounds. Since only about 30% of 2016 is left, the probability ought to be around 2-3% at this stage.

I'm not worried about the Eighteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Pakistan which basically prevents the Pakistan President from removing the PM.  The only way by law to remove the is for the Parliament to have a vote of no confidence with at least a 20% of the electorate.  But then you have the Military who could kill him or he could die of natural causes.  I don't think either will happen rather elections will be held and he will leave office in the Spring of 2017.  The last few PMs were around 66-67 years old when they left office and their time as PM was about 3 years.  Sharif meets both of those criteria.

There's no chink in his standing. I think his third stint is going to be substantially better, undoing some of the damage he did in his earlier stints. This should keep the educated middle-class happier, while the conservatives don't have too many other places to turn.

Extended convalescence in London may have done him the world of good, but gee, it's been a long break from his home country. Will review in another month, or sooner if a major crisis hits the fan.

As Sharif's condition improves, his grip on power strengthens. The opposition have failed to land any meaningful blows on him in his absence - Imran Khan's sister was even forced to offer a formal, public apology to Sharif's daughter, which says something about the authority that he and his dynasty retain. The chances of him ceasing to be Prime Minister are becoming markedly slimmer. Worth revisiting this question again in a week.

Reasons why Nawaz Sharif will remain:
Nawaz exit scare receded, PM heading back home

Sharif has now been absent for almost a month because of his operation, and seems still to be firmly in charge. Various media outlets both inside and outside Pakistan are swinging behind him (perhaps as other players in the region realise that his strong leadership presents the best chance of keeping a lid on the insurgency in Pakistan, and preventing it from spilling over). Moreover, the opposition have failed to make significant gains: a petition calling for his removal on the grounds of corruption was recently presented, but seems to be gaining little popular (or legal) traction; attempts to declare his absence unconstitutional are also not making progress. A letter supposedly written by Sharif personally opposing India's admission to the Nuclear Suppliers Group is also being heavily publicised in Pakistan - this is a highly populist move designed to shore up popular support throughout the country.
Unlikely. Corrupt system in Pakistan means accountability is unlikely

COMMENT:
Regurgitating  "media gobbledigup" in a controlled political environment such as Pakistan fails to address the critical questions.
He'll return to Pakistan on the third day of Eid. That's July 8th, I think: http://92newshd.tv/pm-nawaz-sharif-to-return-country-on-3rd-day-of-eid/

Sharif's daughter posted a picture of Nawaz after surgery on twitter.  Why was the picture posted?  To let folks know he made it through surgery?  Nawaz looks weak in the picture.  He looks vulnerable.  Should I have pity on him?  Should we have empathy?  Should I be relieved he made it?  Reassured he will be ok?  The picture is grainy.  I can't make out the vital signs of the monitor above his head, the ET tube does not look secured, the ART-line transducer is not at the phlebostatic axis, where is the CVP and swan transducers, where is the ventilator?  Ventilator tubes are not that long the Vent should be on the other side of the bed, where are the chest tubes, pacemaker and on and on.....who is this picture intended for?  Not me, not the rest of the healthcare community.  Maybe other world leaders or the general Pakistan population more like it.  Everyday Pakistanis would not have a clue.  How would an everyday Pakistanis view this picture?  How about Pakistanis leaders?  It may not be politically viable for Pakistani opposition leaders to form a coup or somehow subvert Sharif's leadership while he is recovering from heart surgery that may backfire.  Perhaps this is all about something else?  What I have no idea.

Sharif is 67 and has a history of heart problems. He had successful open heart surgery in London in June, 2016 (his second visit to London for medical attention in 2016), but his health problems and the protracted absences from Pakistan that they have caused have led to calls for an interim Prime Minister to be elected in his stead in the last month. An attempt by Ishaq Dar, the Pakistani finance minister, to act as PM in Sharif's absence have triggered a constitutional crisis, leading to demands for his immediate return to office. There is some speculation that this is a ploy by the opposition to force Sharif's hand - if he is not well enough to return to office, and another cannot act as PM in his place, then this could trigger an immediate general election, or at least the official appointment of a caretaker PM.
Pakistan does not oust its leaders based on int'l opinion

Decently long time frame but I did not want to forecast this question earlier, as predicting Pakistani politics is tougher than calling a coin toss. Ok, so Panama Papers is a big deal but by itself not enough to see Sharif going. However, vacating office for any reason counts. Health can be one. Panama Papers another. A coup - well there have been three earlier, though this is a low probability event to my mind. So three buckets. Panama Papers etc - 60%, Health - 30% (half of P.P), Coup etc - 10% (one tenth of total). I give 40% of bucket 1 in toto, 50% of bucket 2 in toto, and 20% of bucket 3. Adding up - 24% + 15 + 2% = 41%. Hence 41%.

There are moves by the opposition for an investigation by a military body within the polity.  Whether the legislative action will pass or not in the lower house will depend on the minimum winning coalition for the PM.  If a military body does the investigation there is an unlikely chance that this matter will receive significant attention and problems for the PM.   The military is key to the minimum winning coalition.

The current elected government has been in power for eight years. Since 1947 civilian governments have lasted respectively 11 years, 6 years and 11 years again before being overthrown by the military. So Pakistan's history suggests the possibility of a coup in the next few years. Lets start by assuming an even money chance of a coup sometime in the next four years. The allegations of corruption against Sharif's family suggest that a coup, if it is to happen, will more than likely occur for a publicly justifiable reason, and is therefore most likely in the remaining months of 2016, though early 2017 is still quite possible. Lets say that if it happens its an 80% chance of occurring in 2016. That lowers my assessment of the odds to 50%*80%=40%. However history also suggests that democracy is taking hold-2013 gave Pakistan the first civilian transfer of power after the successful completion of a five year term by a democratically elected government. Presumably also the military has a weather eye on the chaos that has ensued in the middle east after the overthrow of governments, albeit not democratic ones. I will arbitrarily calculate that each of these factors halves the potential risks and bring my forecast down to 40%*1/2*1/2=10%. The next  factor to consider is Sharif pledging to resign if found to be corrupt. At the moment he has plausible deniability as the allegations concern his family and not him. I believe that an inquiry will be under international pressure to keep Pakistan's democracy on track for fear of Pakistan's nuclear capabilities. Basis this I'll leave the odds where they are. However a couple of other possibilities to consider are 1) Sharif personally getting implicated as more documents are revealed and 2) Sharif being the victim of a plane crash, bombing or even his death from natural causes. I think these factors combined increase the odds by 1) 10% and 2) 3%. Total 23%

Hypothesis:
Pakistan is a fascinating place. On the one hand, one of the most uncertain geopolitical environments along w/ a number of historically corrupt political actors. On the other hand, one of the best performing stock markets over the past five years w/ close to a 25% compounded annual return!
The power in Pakistan till resides in the army and the ISI. Very doubtful they would get rid of him, but they have removed others.
The only way,he can be removed is by the Army and that seems highly unlikely in 2016

Pakistan is facing large national security issues at the moment, namely from Islamic militancy (TPP), which American drones have been helping combat. National security will trump PM allegations for the public interest.

Various preference choices are possible for this particular outcome, which other forecasters have noted, could (and most likely)  have nothing to do with the Panama Papers itself.  This constrains the preference set to a small number of choices and consequently, with one outcome (leaving office), preferences over choices are an extremely small set.  Since corruption, patronage and de facto military/ruling elite coalition are prominent features of the Pakistani polity, one should expect that the PM's minimum winning coalition will remain in tact.    Therefore, given the function, g: X --> A  choices under conditions of certainty, require that {a1, ...., a(k)} be mapped topologically as one member of A to the outcome set X. X = {x1, ...,  x(n)}.  this constraint requires that the conditional action or choice in a maximized choice set suggest that the only option that would result in an outcome of the PM leaving office, is when he no longer has the support of the minimum winning coalition in the polity.   If this conditional outcome requires a negative action (or choice) compared to the previous preference, then the outcome will suggest a likely possibility that the PM will leave office.  However, given that the PM leaving office requires a choice set of A = {coercion, loss of a minimum coalition, and significant threat toward the PM}, this would be analytically and theoretically support leaving office.  However, given that corruption in Pakistan is deeply ingrained in its polity and the Panama Papers revelation has been open knowledge in Pakistan for some time, we can deduce with a high degree of confidence that the PM will not leave office.   While he is left with an uncomfortable option if explaining the matter, it does not change the actions and choice which will lead to him leaving office.

Another US drone strike in Pakistan, this one killing somebody's favourite Taliban mullah.  Sooner or later the Pakistani military are going to tire of this, as it makes them look ineffectual.  (They may of course be covertly complicit, but it still makes them look ineffectual.)  They are not likely to smile upon a PM who permits This Sort of Thing.  The Panama Papers remain irrelevant unless the military use them as a pretext.  In the past, they have not much relied on pretexts.  Stay tuned.
Reducing from my initial 45% as it is beginning to look like Nawaz will be able to drag this out. However, there is considerable uncertainty, as the following op-ed indicates..
Pak PM's are perpetually perched precariously.
Not enough international condemnation so far.
There are many interesting and colourful ways to "cease being Prime Minister of Pakistan," but the Panama Papers are unlikely to increase the overall odds.
Such allegations are common in India and Pakistan, only possible cause of stepping down would be if Pakistan Miltary and ISI are not on his side

Panama paper leaks have not created the momentum to dislodge the sitting Prime Minister but there could be other events that could trigger such a move and Government also has the option to call snap elections. Opposition does not have enough votes to dislodge the PM nor are they united, if any entity can force change then that is GHQ, prime beneficiary of civilian chaos. Starting with a low probability but keeping a close eye on what happens in the streets of Lahore, Riyadh and Beijing.

Sharif asked the opposition and other lawmakers to help form a parliamentary commission.
Previous efforts to have a retired or sitting Supreme Court judge chair a judicial commission have stalled as all the judges rejected the offer.
It is not clear if the opposition will take up Sharif’s latest offer. They walked out soon after Sharif stopped speaking, angered that seven questions they posed to him ahead of the parliamentary session were not answered.
“Not a single question has been answered by the PM,” said Khursheed Shah, leader of the opposition in the National Assembly.
Imran Khan, leader of the opposition PTI party, said: “We didn’t need to hear such a long story. He could have shown the documents as I have done so.”
Opposition politicians said they would announce on Tuesday their response to Sharif’s speech.

All in all looks like there will be lots of talking but no real changes (4) related to the Panama papers so for that I'd say <5%, however some other as yet unanticipated event(s) might facilitate his departure so raising the forecast slightly.
